forehand.description: The forehand is typically a player's most powerful and reliable stroke, hit on the dominant side of the body.

technique.grip: Eastern, Semi-Western, or Western grip depending on playing style
technique.preparation: Unit turn with racquet back, non-dominant hand guides the racquet
technique.contact_point: Out in front of the body, at about waist height
technique.follow_through: Across the body, finishing high over the opposite shoulder

common_mistakes: Contact point too late or too close to the body
Grip too loose or too tight

backhand.description: The backhand can be hit with one or two hands and is crucial for defensive and offensive play.

one_handed.preparation: Turn sideways early, racquet back with non-dominant hand support
one_handed.contact_point: Slightly ahead of the front hip

two_handed.grip: Continental grip with dominant hand, Eastern forehand with non-dominant
two_handed.preparation: Compact backswing with both hands on racquet
two_handed.contact_point: Closer to the body than one-handed

serve.description: The serve is the most important stroke in tennis as it starts every point.

technique.toss: Consistent placement slightly in front and to the right (for right-handers)
technique.motion: Fluid upward motion with racquet drop behind the back
technique.contact: At full arm extension, hitting up and out

types: Slice serve - Curves away from opponent
Kick serve - High bounce with topspin

volley.description: Volleys are hit before the ball bounces, typically at the net.

technique.grip: Continental grip for both forehand and backhand volleys
technique.contact_point: Out in front of the body

volley.strategy: Used to finish points quickly and apply pressure
common_mistakes: Not moving feet to get in good position
